import "./ahc.css" export default function Ahc15() { return (

The cardinal rule of behaviour change

  • 4th law of behaviour change: Make it satisfying
  • While the first three laws are for triggering the action (behaviour) the last law triggers the repetition of the behaviour
  • Our goals and habits are usually meant to give long term results but the human brain always goes for instant gratification
  • Cardinal rule of behavior change: What is immediately rewarded is repeated, what is immedieately punished is avoided
  • The consequences of bad habits are delayed but the rewards are immediate - Smoking cigarette, eating junk food
  • With good habits its the opposite, the immediate outcome is unenjoyable but the ultimate outcome feels good
  • The road less travelled is the road of delayed gratification
  • If you’re willing to wait for the rewards you’ll face less competition and often get better rewards
  • Success in every field requires you to ignore an immediate reward in favor of a delayed reward
  • Add a little bit of pleasure to habits that reward in the long run and a little bit of pain to habits that don’t
  • The vital thing for a habit to be rewarding — feel successful even if it is in a small way
  • In a perfect world, the reward for the habit is the habit itself
  • Immediate reinforcement helps to maintain motivation in the short term while you’re waiting for long term rewards to arrive
  • Eventually intrinsic rewards like better mood, reduced stress and more energy kicks in you’ll be less concerned with chasing the secondary reward
) }
